t: “Today*pn also my complaint is bitter; my*ld hand is heavy on account of my groaning.
Oh,*ln that I knew where I might find him, that*ld I might come even to his seat!
I*ln would lay my case before him and*ld fill my mouth with arguments.
I*ln would know what he would answer me and*ld understand what he would say to me.
Would*ln he contend with me in the greatness of his power? No;*ld he would pay attention to me.
There*ln an upright man could argue with him, and*ld I would be acquitted forever by my judge.
“Behold,*pn I go forward, but he is not there, and*ld backward, but I do not perceive him;
on*ln the left hand when he is working, I do not behold him; he*ld turns to the right hand, but I do not see him.
But*ln he knows the way that I take; when*ld he has tried me, I shall come out as gold.
My*ln foot has held fast to his steps; I*ld have kept his way and have not turned aside.
I*ln have not departed from the commandment of his lips; I*ld have treasured the words of his mouth more than my portion of food.
But*ln he is unchangeable, and who can turn him back? What*ld he desires, that he does.
For*ln he will complete what he appoints for me, and*ld many such things are in his mind.
Therefore*ln I am terrified at his presence; when*ld I consider, I am in dread of him.
God*ln has made my heart faint; the*ld Almighty has terrified me;
yet*ln I am not silenced because of the darkness, nor*ld because thick darkness covers my face.
